commentBody: Deepest condolences to you and his loved ones, Deb. These are such lovely and poignant memories that you share - proving that they are a blessing.
I suppose most solvers over 35 will have missed it, but (E)DNAMODE(L) was the big giveaway for me
I'm so sorry for your loss Deb. My heart goes out to you.
Sorry about your dad, Deb, but that was a beautiful story. Thank you for sharing.
I'm sorry for your loss

Deb,
May his memory be a blessing.
I'm so sorry for your loss.
I found that difficult--very slow time.
My condolences to you and your family.  Peace be with you.

Deb,

As one who recently lost a parent with whom I shared a love of crosswords, I feel your grief.  My condolences. Through the magic of words and crosswords, though, your father will always be with you.

How eerie is that this puzzle clues Trent Reznor, whose music I came to via Johnny Cash’s poignant version of his song Hurt.

Sorry for your loss Deb.
I loved this puzzle, such a lovely theme and theme set.    Not sure if there are a lot of other theme words that work but I doubt they would be as clever. I also thought the clueing was above average—not a fan of SPASMS and PRE but the rest were top notch.
Deb, what a beautiful, loving tribute to your late father. So saddened by your loss.

Deb- So sorry for your loss.
That hardly seems like a deep enough thing to say, but it does come from the heart.
I lost both my parents some time ago but they never leave me.
Not as long as I think about them, whether I smile or frown.

Deb, I am so sorry. What a lovely, moving tribute you have shared with us.

Almost 27 years on, I still have the last NYT crossword puzzle my Dad tried to complete in his final days in ICU. He and my mother introduced me to the daily discipline of completing the Times crossword. It is so reassuring to renew that connection with them every time I start filling in a new puzzle.

Sorry for your loss, Deb and happy for your memories!

This was a great Thursday puzzle. At first, it seemed easy but there were some difficulties.  Last to fall was SKIP AD which I was thinking was going to be one word.
I'm so sorry for your loss, Deb. I used to watch my dad do acrostics. And he'd do them like you often say. He'd work on it a bit put it down and come back to it.

My parents had the Sunday NYT delivered when I was growing up, just the Sunday paper.  My mother, who had only a high school education, did the crossword in the Magazine.  She solved as her bathroom entertainment and didn't do it in one sitting; if you used the bathroom, you'd see it in various stages of completion, on Monday, on Tuesday...eventually, it would be done.

It was something I remember clearly now but paid little note of then.

My mother and I never worked crosswords together; I'd never shown any interest in doing so as a kid.  But sometime during college or shortly thereafter, I took them up.  I guess in the back of my mind, I was a grownup now, and crosswords were things grownups did.  

As it turns out, I don't think I ever made much mention at any time to my mother that I started solving crosswords, before she died over 15 years ago.  But here I am, having done them for over 45 years by now, every day, finishing every one for at least the past 15 years, maybe more.

It's funny how some things run in the family.

Dear Deb,
Thanks for sharing this sweet story about your dad. He sounds like a fine person. May memories like these offer you comfort and peace. 

My good wishes to you and your family.

Deb, I’m very sorry for your loss. I love the image of young Deb helping your dad with his crossword as a “solving team.” I’m sure your father cherished those memories as well. It has been our good fortune that your father introduced you to the wonderful world of crosswords. Loved the puzzle. A gentle but very clever and elegant theme. So many great STEELY Dan songs but “Reelin’ in the Years” contains one of my favorite lyrics: “You been tellin' me you're a genius since you were seventeen In all the time I've known you I still don't know what you mean” https://youtube.com/watch?v=5b6fPnBtUqw
Condolences on the passing of your dad.  It is hard to lose a parent, no matter our age.

First, wow Deb, very sorry for your loss and a touching column.  Your dad sounds terrific.

Moving awkwardly to our normal triviality, my only regret about this puzzle is that the cluing was so easy that I didn't really have adequate time to enjoy and appreciate the theme. The theme answers were all so well done that I think they deserve a better supporting puzzle.

On the other hand perhaps it's hard to make these theme answers themselves hard, since the first, pretty obvious answer fills all but the last square anyway.  It took me 2 or 3 to "get" the theme (the revealer wasn't great or needed) and it made me smile.


Anyhoo, a nice run, if just too easy for Thursday.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Thanks for sharing. That was beautiful!
So sorry for your loss! May his memory always be a blessing! He will always be there with you! My father passed over 60 years ago! He’s never far from my mind! He did crosswords, too!

Deb, thanks for deciding to share with us about your dad. My condolences to you.

I also like hearing other folks’ parental puzzle memories.

Mine is me and my sister helping mom with the acrostic.  I still remember how we cracked each other up once when somehow an answer that was supposed to be “toodle-oo” ended up being “noodle-on”.  We made use of “noodle-on” as a goodbye saying for years.  People probably wondered about us…
I have never seen BRUH before that I can recall and I don’t think PUCKS ‘ ‘seek’ the goal so I was stuck with PaCK and BRaH and had no idea where I went wrong.

Oh, Deb, what a very sad time you're going through. I'm so very sorry. I know your father's memory will always be a blessing to you and yours. Thank you so much for sharing your heart and story with us. We all care about you very much! As for the puzzle, much like you, I also wanted [Genesis creator] to be Robert Palmer or Phil Collins. Here is one of Mr. Collins' favorite songs from his time with Genesis: https://youtu.be/jpmiZ7zsHXY?feature=shared As for the theme, this is the kind of play with the language that just blows my mind. CLOSES SHOP/LOSES HOPE. APRÈS SKI/PRESS KIT. How brilliant the minds that can come up with these! - in this case, the brilliant minds of Rebecca and Adam. What a dynamic duo! Thank you so much to the two of you for this terrific puzzle.

Woo! First to the column by Deb: as a word-loving dad who has a couple word-loving children, nothing makes such a parent prouder and happier than to share word-loving like that, and even better if you know they're going to be OK, as you put it, so good on you for contributing in some alchemical way to increasing the time he remained alive: you (and the rest of his family) made his life that much more worth living a little longer. You can see that pride and joy in other word-loving parents, too, like when Strudel Dad comments, or, back in the day when Rachel's Mom would stop by once in a while.

To the puzzle: a lot of fun, thoroughly witty and modern, very 21st century but with a dash of Wodehouse to it. For too long I had LOCUST for CICADA. (Are you a Ci-CAY-duh person or a Ci-CAH-da sort? I'm the former, my wife the latter.) But I also put down SHIPLASH, 

I sorta hoped that end letters to the themers would have spelled some word, the kind of extra feature that cause some of us to go insane on this chatline, but all it spelt out was MECATELT. 

Also liked the clandestine OPTICAL common core of this puzzle, with its SPYING through a PEEPHOLE, and what do you see? Some model named Edna giving herself a steely, leery look into the mirror as she applies primer? Or Trent Reznor at home, getting riled into spasms by the presence of an oboe in the theme song to "The Queen's Gambit" which he's about to watch, while having consommé and a nice, dry Rhone?

Nice fill, but this was too easy, and the theme was very weak for a Thursday.

5/10.
Bruh?

So touching, Deb. I'm just a month ahead of you with the death of my mom, but if you're like me, your breathing will come back, your shoulders will eventually drop back down, and your heart will find its normal rhythm again. You're in my thoughts.

So, I just teared up too, Deb, because my Dad taught me how to do crosswords and play dominoes. He also taught his 3 grand daughters the domino game to help them learn their multiplication tables. Weren't we lucky ?! Love your columns, keep up the good work!
Deb, I’m sorry to hear about your father. I hope pleasant memories such as the one about “helping” your dad solve crosswords bring you some solace.
Very sad, Deb. No parent could hope for more than to inspire the kind of feeling that your father did. Peace.

Deb, My heart goes out to you with the loss of your father. I’m touched by you sharing with us what made your father so special, in ways big and small.
I always turn to your blog to help with my daily solving and I appreciate the hints, insights and fun take on solving. Today is special for how you shared your dad with us.

Some amazing clues here, especially ATOM, MAR and MIRROR. Other clues were iffy. PEEPHOLE’s clue should have had a “?” at the end, IMO. The theme itself was okay. 

But how can you have STEELY in there and not reference Dan in the clue? That’s just absurd.
Thanks for sharing that lovely story about your father Deb. Thinking of you during what must be a very challenging last few weeks. I hope you can find solace in his passing, knowing he's at peace.

Wow, Deb. What a legendary man. And what a gift your story is. I’m sure you could write pages but sometimes you can say more with fewer words. I dig it. The sadness won’t go away but you can learn to enjoy it. And soon he’ll show up in your dreams. But not right away.

I’m so sorry for your loss, Deb. My grandma taught me how to do crosswords and the day she died, I did the one in the paper and tucked it into her blankets to be taken away with her. I hope the memories of puzzling with your dad bring you comfort.
Deb, my condolences to you on the loss of your father.
Deb, thank you for sharing your touching memories of your dad. Mine's been gone for seven years (he was also 91) and his example guides me still.

Deb--

Very sorry to hear about the loss of your father.  My Dad passed on last June at age 96.  He wasn't a crossword solver, but he loved puns, and the staff in his Memory Care unit all noticed the twinkle in his eye when he invariably corrected their grammar.  I think the last time he reminded me to say "Mary and me," not "Mary and I," was Christmas 2023, when he was 95.

On the other hand, my six year-old granddaughter now eagerly watches  and occasionally helps me solve the crossword, Wordle, and other games when we are together.  I enjoy the thought of her solving on into the 22nd century.  Please make sure the NYT puzzles are still good then.

Deb, so sorry for your loss. Your story really parallels that of my grandfather who is the one who introduced me to the Sunday crossword when I was in second grade. He too would pretend like he couldn’t solve a clue and ask for my help when he thought I might know the answer. As I reflect back on it now, it amazes me that he was able to complete them based on the fact that Spanish was his first language and he only went to school through 9th grade. He was a proud member of the 82nd Airborne. He was 92 when he passed away. I’m cherishing the memories that you stirred up today and I hope your memories with your dad can offer you comfort in this difficult time. 

Rebecca and Adam, thank you for this one. Clever clues and theme!!

A poignant column opener, condolences to you and your family, Deb Amlen.

Fitting that the puzzle itself was a good one. No junk, no naticks.

Oh Deb. I'm so sorry. May his memory be a blessing.

My own mother loved doing the daily crossword - with pencil to newsprint - to keep her mind sharp. I started doing them later in life after observing the joy and satisfaction she derived from solving them during our weekly family get-togethers. And after a time, I too was hooked.

Mom passed in 2022 due to a body that unfortunately couldn't keep up with her abundent mental abilities. I miss her every day, and think of her while entering letters into the grid.

May the crossword puzzle tradition continue the memory.

Deb, my deepest condolences to you as you remember and honor your father. Thank you so much for sharing his story with us, including his love of puzzles and his impact he had on you. Sending you and your family peace, compassion, and love during this time.
Condolences Deb.

Your story about your dad pierces the heart.  It includes all of it, the conflict and closeness, the respect and defiance, the values he taught you and the distance that can happen when you have been told to stick to your guns and you're on opposite sides of an argument.  In the end, it's all distilled into the depth of feeling when the last hours are spent with a part of yourself you must say goodbye to.  A scrap of paper can hold so much meaning, and you are blessed to still have it.

Thank you for coming back to tell us what just happened and what gave you and us your commitment to a game that is for many of us so much more than a game.

So very sorry for your loss Deb. A fitting reminder to let go of the things that divide us and embrace that which binds us together, especially in this polarizing environment we find ourselves in. And a good reminder that we never know how much time we have with our loved ones. I lost both my parents young so envy those special years you had with your dad. Thoughts and prayers with you, your mom, and all who loved your dad.

Deb, your column was a worthy tribute to your dad. Thank you for sharing a bit of the textured life you had with him. The fact that you always had crosswords in common is a testament to the love you shared. That you were able to build an amazing career on the primary way you connected with him demonstrates the power of your relationship. May your family find peace. 💐 

The puzzle was an ideal Thursday. Excellent collaboration! I had to peek at the column a couple of times but it was not because of bad clueing. I just needed more confidence. Great job 👍🏾.

So sorry, Deb. A lovely story about your Dad. It really got to me - thank you for sharing it. My Mom and I would spend long car rides doing crosswords together. Those are some of my fondest memories of us together. 

This was a fun Thursday. Let’s hope our once-vaunted public education system can find its way back to its common core values.

Such a nice remembrance, Deb.

I like to think that somehow, somewhere, he's reading it.

I lost my dad on January 6, nine years ago— such a dreary time of year, a funeral in the snow, but I’m always so happy we had the holidays together. I hope you did as well and I am so sorry for your loss. Thank you for sharing and making me think of my dad today. You’re not alone <3

I very nearly hit the reef on that one.  Finally I got away from STEadY for 44D, and got to STEELY.

That was really a close one.  Fun one, too.
What a great remembrance, Deb. So sorry for your loss.
What a tender tribute to your father.  Now I’m tearing up thinking of my own.  Wishing you peace and comfort in your grief.
My heartfelt condolences Deb, thank you for sharing this lovely tribute to your father.
Beautiful, Deb. Condolences to you and your family.
What a lovely remembrance. Thank you for sharing.

Deb - what a beautiful way to remember and honor your father. So sorry for your loss. I'm sure he was truly proud of you - his solving teammate / puzzle partner. You made it to the puzzling big leagues, even! 

Sending all the love your way and hoping you continue to live life with curiosity and gratitude. Xx

PS - today's puzzle was a lot of fun, especially for a Thursday.

@Deb - Lovely tribute and heartfelt condolences. Sorry for your loss and may you have all strength to bear it. 

The puzzle was excellent. Enjoyed grokking the trick which I figured out quite early on in the solve. But not knowing about the nomenclature of a common syllabus stopped me from completing for a while - I had COMMONCOdE, and for some reason thought that was okay - till I saw that RIG was better fit than dIG. And then of course the revealer was super apt!
Deb, my heart goes out to you. Sending warm fuzzies.

Well, I solved the puzzle but after Deb's column I don't even recall it now. So sorry for your loss, Deb. And it made me remember my own father. He was a wonderful man and we were always so close when I was growing up. But then... 

He was B-17 pilot whose plane was shot down over Germany  during World War II, and he spent almost the last year of the war in POW camp. When I came back from Vietnam after my second purple heart, that bond grew so much closer and it would be hard to describe how wonderful it was to be able to relate with him about our experiences. Some sadness, of course, but a lot of hilarity as well. Hard to explain. I'll probably be thinking about it a lot today. 

Again, so sorry for your loss. Take care. 

...
Under no reasonable definition of "Tech" could AOL be considered an "Early Giant"

After reading Deb's testimonial it seems irrelevant, but here goes . . . 

Strands Thread.  Post no spoilers until the View All Replies button: 


Strands #319
“Bar association”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

Dear Deb: Thank you for sharing this loving tribute. May his memory be a blessing.
I, too, would do the Sunday crossword with Dad. One of the proudest moments for both of us happened a few years after college.
I went to visit my parents at their condo. Early Sunday morning I got the NYT from outside the door where it was delivered.
When my Dad came into the kitchen somewhat later, I was able to present to him the completed crossword and the acrostic(this was close to 50 years ago).
He looked at it and then me and smiled and said I guess that liberal arts education was not wasted.

Rebecca's original clue (Label on a spot remover) for SKIP AD was crossword gold.  Much more clever than the one used.

Exceptional clue for ATOM.

I cried a little, 
but not because of this splendid puzzle.

Every morning, I’m so lucky to get
to hang out with my dad. 
We do the crossword and he
heaps praise on every little square I fill in,
no matter how obvious the clue.

“Man, you’re a smart one, CC! WOW!”
“How did you get that so fast?”

He died in 1991.
But he’s here with me and the puppies,
grandsons, and son-in-law he never knew.

But I think he does. 
He knows it all.

Deb, my tears are falling on my iPad as
I *promise* you-
he’ll be here, peeking over your shoulder,
every
single
day.

How lucky we are.

And I’m so incredibly saddened 
and sorry for your loss.

Thanks Deb, for sharing that heartfelt tribute. I have been on a similar journey with my dad the past few years, and I try to call him daily because we really don't know how much longer we have with him. 

As for the puzzle, I had to smirk when the one letter that I couldn't get without peeking at the answer was the U in BRUH. I had BRAH instead . . . I guess I thought PACKS seek goals too?? With a 11- and soon-to-be 13-year-old, I've heard countless iterations of BRUH, BRAH, and now everyone (including females) just get called BRO. Needless to say, my kids would be none too impressed with my solving skills today :) 

My one nit with the puzzle is OBSCENEST, especially since it is part of the first themed answer. Is it technically a word, sure, but so is OBSCUREST, and it is most obscure to see either word in -est form!

My deepest sympathies on the loss of your Dad. What a heartfelt tribute. I can relate as I lost my Dad at the age of 92 a few years ago. I enjoy your column and insights immensely, as Thursday puzzles always present a challenge. Your self -deprecating humor and wit shine through as you lead us to the solution.
Deb, your love shimmers through your words, and as you poured out your heart, you touched mine.  Deep condolences for your loss.

My condolences, Deb, on your great loss. I feel so flattered that you should share your grief with us, your on-line commentariat family. What an impressive puzzle! To come up with four real-language pairs of eight- or nine-letter words, which share all but one of those letters--well wow! Not to mention A TO M--that should certainly make it onto L's Monday morning list! It makes up for BR-H: I was going to ask my homies, but they're not all that good at spelling, so I ran the vowels instead. Ah, that kind of goal! Here's two musical offerings with ties to my hometown of Cleveland, Ohio: Here's an old friend playing one which isn't black: https://youtube.com/watch?v=W_tcbHZPNrA I didn't know him, but here's some grainy footage of Mr. Reznor from before his NIN days: https://youtube.com/watch?v=NtbsTP9aOZA (The band was formed by a couple of percussion majors from the Cleveland Institute of Music, and took their name from the work "Oiseaux Exotiques." by the French composer Olivier Messaien. I was always surprised they never made it out of the local circuit.)

Deb, I'm so sorry for your loss. Such nice memories.

Fun puzzle today. Never heard of EDNAMODE, but there were clearly no other options. The other themers added up, almost like a non-rebus rebus. The first one I got was MOBSCENE__ and that seemed so right that I just decided to see what happened. 

Thanks!

So many cool answers that maybe took a moment to get, but made me smile when I got the witty answer. 

My condolences to you, Deb. I lost my dad 26 years ago and I still mourn all that he missed with my family and all that we missed with him. He was a painter, so our home is filled with his work—he is always present, and for that I am grateful. Puzzles will do the same for you, I’m sure. Peace be with your dad and for you and your family.

Deb, I'm very sad to hear the news about your father. Your story makes me think of my own mom, who also introduced me to crosswords when I was a child.

She will be 97 in a few months, but she still does puzzles daily. She sticks to the large print, easy ones now, as she only has one good eye, her memory is failing, and her hands shake a bit when she holds the pen.... but her puzzling enthusiasm has never faded.

I enjoyed today's puzzle. The theme wasn't too tricky for a Thursday, but it was clever, and the clues were tricky enough (for me, anyway). 

I went a few minutes over my average, mostly because I got stuck in the SE corner. I had "steady" for 44D, which really messed up my crosses. It was 42D SKIP AD that finally straightened me out. I would probably still be stuck on it if the diabolical original clue had been used. 😄

I'm so sorry for you loss, Deb.  Thank you for sharing the wonderful story of you and your dad.  My grandmother was the puzzler in our family.  I was dazzled that she could do the Sunday NYT crossword puzzle with a pen, and that inspired me to start doing them too, with a pen.  I do them now online, but she, and also my mom, were my inspiration.

Sending a big hug at this difficult time.
Deb, thank you for sharing that with us. Your dad didn’t just get to see you doing OK and doing what you love. He got to see you doing it really, really well.

So sorry to learn of your dad's death, Deb.  Condolences.  And ... you reminded me of how I first came to love crossword puzzles, as I savored the finished diagrams in the daily NYT, having been solved perfectly by my dad.  That was back in Margaret Farrar's day.  And today's puzzle.  Wow.  I just want to say how beautiful those theme answers were.  What amazing finds!

This, the first NYT collab from this pair, seemed destined to be a winner.  Two constructing pros with a penchant for Thursdays, and who each have a twinkle in their eye, with the knack for keeping the solver in a good mood.

I felt that twinkle, for example, in clues such as [Something a meter reader reads], and [First half of a two-volume encyclopedia on physics, aptly?].

I appreciated their skill in 
•	Coming up with this remarkable theme set at all. How did they do it?  Was it, as yesterday’s constructor said, “… thinking really hard”?  Was a computer involved?  Would Rebecca and/or Adam like to chime in here? 
•	Seeding beauty into the box with PINGED, MOB SCENE, APRES SKI, LAST LEGS, CICADA, CLOSE SHOP and WHIPLASH.

For some reason, as I scanned the completed grid, my eyes fell on the HOP of HOPE, and the POP of POPIN, and I was thrust back to that glorious period when one of my sons was enamored with Dr. Seuss’s HOP on POP, and, as if I were there again, I relived his excitement and joy. 

So, smiles, respect, and heart-warming memories rising out of the box for me, Rebecca and Adam.  A winner indeed. How about some more … please?  Thank you for a very sweet solve!

Deb, what a beautiful tribute to your beloved father. I am so sorry for your loss. Thank you so much for sharing such a moving story with us! The part where you solved the puzzles with your dad was so cute. I can picture a tiny Deb leaning over your dad, excitedly telling him the answer. I’m so glad you have such fond memories with him!

This puzzle was a fun one for me. A breezier Thursday was just what I needed after a particularly frigid week here in Chicago. Have a wonderful day, everyone!
I'm so sorry for your loss, Deb. That was a beautiful tribute to your dad. Condolences to you and your family.
I’m so sorry for your loss. Thank you for sharing your memories with us - it was a lovely tribute.

Oh Deb, what a sad loss for you and your family, but what lovely memories you were able to make before he died. I’m so glad you’re able to look back at your lives together and take comfort from knowing how much he loved you and how proud he was of you and your sister. 
My Dad and I were also frequently at loggerheads; sadly our issues were not resolved at the point of his death 26 years ago, both of us too proud and stubborn. It’s an ongoing regret I carry.

Today’s crossword is very clever, if a little simpler than the average, Rebi infested Thursday, for which I’m thankful on a gloomy foggy day at the rough end of January. Ready for Spring now, enough with the rain already. Every dog walk is a swim through mud. Ugh.

For all those complaining about 50A:
The correct spelling is [*bruh₃], from the Indo-European root for "dude," using the conventional notation for the third, o-colored laryngeal.

In the scholarly linguistic community, there is some argument on the realized pronunciation of the initial asterisk, at least by paleolithic fratboys.

Many condolences, Deb, on the passing of your father. Your beautifully-written tribute, and the many lovely notes in this feed from others who have lost parents (esp those parents who onboarded us to crosswords!) is bringing tears to my eyes too. I count myself among those whose dad did the crossword and got me hooked too, with joy at the wordplay, the infinite possibilities of language and nuance, and the thrill of the solve. I miss him … an oddity is that when I do the rare pen-to-ink xword (say, in an in-flight magazine), my fill is structured capital letters, a little cramped and not really like I usually write — but an awful lot like dad’s penmanship.
I'm glad that you used today's column to share thoughts of your wonderful dad! So sorry for your loss.

So sorry for you loss, Deb; thank you for sharing with all of us.

anaheim mighty DUCKS works pretty darn well, at least as well in my opinion, for 47D; "goal seekers".   I wonder if anyone else went down the wrong path there.

Seemed more an odd Wednesday than a true Thursday puzzle to me, but certainly suitable for today as well.

Got the theme at MOBSCENEST, which helped me complete the other thematic entries. Never heard of Edna Mode, but the theme required EDNAMODEL, so I confidently filled that in.

APRESSKIT was my favorite, since APRESSKI and PRESSKIT seem so unrelated otherwise. That said, I'm almost sorry to add that I found the puzzle a bit of a slog. Solved it unaided, but didn't really enjoy doing so. Perhaps another one of those puzzles that is more interesting to create than it is to solve. 

Time to see how others felt.

Was all done, but no music, so went through the acrosses and they all seemed OK.  Then the downs, and came to PaCKS, which I never did figure out how that worked for "Goal seekers", but BRaH seemed correct.  So I cycled through the vowels of BR_H, tried the "U" and that did it.  Guess my age showed on that one, bruh.

Even with flyspecking -- what a strange word, not sure I'd have been able to figure out what it means by just looking at it -- I managed to beat my average by 22%.

I liked the theme which stumped me for a while, but once I got one answer, the others fell pretty quickly.
So sorry to hear about your loss, Deb -- it's really wonderful that your "team solving" when you were a child laid the foundation for your career. Thank you for a lovely tribute to your father.

Oh, Deb, may his memory be a blessing! Its so hard to lose a parent at a "riper" age, because you have the ability to see just how much they have impacted the world, and your own life, and yearn for that connection even more. Blessings to you and your family.
So sorry for the loss of your father. But how sweet, and beautiful, that his love of crosswords brought you here.

Thank you, Deb, for sharing memories of your father.  I wonder how many of us solvers got an early start from a family member.  With me, it was my gramma.  I was around twelve.  I remember sitting with her in her closed in porch in summer and helping her solve the puzzles.  That got me started on a life long hobby.

And today's was a great puzzle.  I loved the wit of the 'two-way'. The last to fall was the 'bruh' and 'puck' crosser.  I had 'brah' and 'pack'.  Thank you all!

The puzzle aside, Deb, your poignant recounting of your father’s brave battle and how he got you started with the NYT crosswords was something wonderful to share.  I think many of us have similar memories of those we shared the solving experience with.  A departed loved one, a past relationship, their memories are often evoked by the crossword.

So sorry for your loss Deb.
great puzzle! this one was so fun!

I read the clues for 1A and 1D aloud, and DHubby exclaimed, "Wow, NOT up your alley!"  (My biggest fan, yep.)  

So I went down to the bottom of the puzzle and got 52A instantly.  Oh, if only.....(The armed forces in the US are having a tough time recruiting because so many candidates lack basic core competency-especialy in reading.  It's no longer a haven for the near-illiterate....)  

Then I scratched around and caught on to the trick--wow!
LAST LAPS before the OBOES interfered.  A lot of clever clues in this one!!

TIL the correct spelling of LEERY. 

Hm! Who knew (other than everyone who can spell)?
Anyone else have BRAH at 50A? I've never seen BRUH used excitedly

Nicely executed grid! The theme seems like it would have the potential to frustrate with non-words in the grid, but I think it worked out really well.

And thank you, Deb, for sharing about your father. It was a very frank, very touching account of a life shaping relationship.
Deb. So sorry about your loss. Sending healing vibes

Deb, my condolences upon your father's death.  May his memory be a blessing. Thank you for telling a bit about him.   My crosswording  also started with my dad's habit of completing the newspaper puzzles every day.

So sorry to hear about your father Deb.

Some nice clues - CONSOMMÉ, ATOM, POEM
Alas, I don't know of The Incredibles, Taylor-Joy, Reznor, COMMON CORE, roasts (not related to cooking) GENESIS, cornhole.

Could someone explain how MOBSCENEST relates to brouhaha and most appalling? Marketing fodder and SKIT?
TSA PRE?
H and ETA?

But hey, I now know MY BAD, I look out for OBOES, (sadly no Oreos today).

For people with epilepsy and some forms of cerebral palsy, SPASMS are not weird but pretty routine.

Such a beautiful tribute to your father, Deb. For so many of us the crossword was a connection to a parent--in my case, my mother. Your presence here is such a boon to us all, and my heart is with you. Thank you for sharing your joys and sorrows with us, and for your work bringing these puzzles to us every week.

Especially puzzles like today's. 21A is one of the best clues I've seen in a while (merely the brightest star among a glittering panoply today). And doesn't one have to adore a puzzlemaker casually dropping a delightful word like "sprezzatura" into the conversation!
Thank you Deb for your memories of your Dad.  I hope my children will think of me, as you do to your father

So sorry for your loss Deb. So many of us have connections to loved ones through crosswords . For me it will always be my Uncle Joe and Aunt Ruth - both gone too many years now . Sending hugs from Maryland . Know that your Dad will be watching every time you solve a puzzle and may occasionally send you an inspiration .
Thank you for your heartfelt words about your father, Deb. A reminder to me to include my kids in my next solve, rather than shooing them away in search of a faster time.

Deb, I cried while reading your  tribute to your father. May his memory be for a blessing. I, too, became a crossword fanatic due to my own father, and in his last years that's what kept him going after the loss of my mother and my younger sister. And that keeps me going, too, in my slightly tarnished golden years.

Sending condolences to Deb.
I, too, inherited my love of the crosswords from my parents. I can picture both my dad's and my mom's handwriting as they filled them in. 
I solve online, but once in a while I catch a whiff of instant coffee mixed with cigarettes - the smell of childhood Sunday mornings. (That sounds gross, but I'm in my 60s and I suspect many of you know what I mean.)

Hi Deb,
As someone who lost her father a little more than a year ago, I would like to offer my deepest condolences, and also some comdort, maybe: They never really leave. Dad's still watching over me, not in a religious sense, but as the loving parent who guided me into adulthood, and far beyond. They'll always be a part of us.

I, too, had a father who worked at Fort Meade and was blessed to share a love of crosswords with him.  Your tribute to him brought back many fond memories of bonding over crosswords and cryptograms with him.  Thank you!
Deb, I'm sitting here with tears streaming down my cheeks. I so loved the memories you shared about your dad. Thank you. I'm terribly sorry for your loss.
bruh moment

Thanks for sharing that thoughtful piece with us , Deb. I echo the support from our community here in expressing sorrow for your loss. I’m so pleased to see you back in the saddle here, it’s been awhile and I missed you.
As for today, I struggled a bit with BRUH vs. BRaH vs. BRoH , but first went with the ‘a’ , figuring baCKS might be seeking goals, as in football running backs. Guess not…

Nice Thursday puzzle. Not my favorite from Rebecca Goldstein - that would be the Alchemy one, which I adored, but this was a pleasant solve. My hangup was in the NW, because I had no clue who EDNA MODE is. Finally got it from the crosses, and done.
@deb What a lovely tribute to your dad.  May his memory be a blessing.
Beautiful tribute, Deb.   You have honored your father brilliantly and I'm sure he is proud.   Well done, and please know a stranger out there is thinking of you and hurting just a bit with you.
Deb, so sorry about your Dad, what a beautiful tribute. Always enjoy your comments and solving help ! Loved this puzzle

My condolences, Deb. I am glad you had so many wonderful years with your dad and that thinking of him brings an emotional response. He seems to have been a great dad. I am happy he introduced you to the world of puzzles.

One of the very few good things I remember about my father was solving crosswords with him. All I learned from him otherwise was how not to be. Fortunately I am a quick study.

I loved today’s crossword! I’m glad Deb drew the lenticular art analogy because that describes it so well.

Thanks Rebecca and Adam for coming up with an unusual twist for today’s themed answers! I really enjoyed solving this one.
Loved the trick with this puzzle! Simple yet super satisfying, probably because the clues were unique too.
I'm so sorry, Deb. Your dad must be so proud of how much everyone here loves and cherishes you.

The only thing more delightful than this Thursday offering are Deb's familial reminiscing. Thank you Deb and Adam for the doubled joy.
"Bruh" is an expression of mild display, not a synonym for "bro."  Every K12 and college teacher knows this...students can say "bruh" meaning, "oh shoot," but please don't call us "bro."
I didn't read wordplay, but condolences. And I am so glad I didn't need any of the "theme" to solve this puzzle. At least it wasn't an annoying rebus.
here is a big red check mark after PRE. It's TSA Recheck. Not weird at all.
Bad Keyboard. There is a big red checkmark after PRE. It's TSA Precheck. Not weird at all.
I'm sorry for your loss, Deb.  What a sweet tribute to your dad.
I guess I'm on Deb's wavelength today. I too thought about Peter Gabriel first for 61A. And I was with my 91-year-old Dad as he passed away in hospice almost three years ago. My condolences Deb.

Thank you to Rebecca and Adam for a terrific puzzle, but more importantly to you, Deb, for sharing the lovely memories of your father.  It's a blessing you were able to be with him at the end.  Those moments, and all of your other memories of him, can never be taken from you.

Deb,

So very sorry on the loss of your Father.Like you,I didn't always agree or understand him,but even after 28 years since his passing,I still miss him every day! May his memory always be a blessing.

My time was 30 minutes longer than my Thursday average and I loved every minute of it.
I am sorry for your loss. Lost years are more precious than gold or diamonds.

My dad just passed last year.  So sorry Deb.  But we are still living, and so wanted you to know I let out a loud Whoop! that scared my wife (don’t ever do that again!) when I finished this puzzle with no look ups.  Perfect puzzle level for me, so crafty, thanks!

Deb, thank you *very* much for a moving, wonderful column that prompted me to think hard about my family and our own relationships.

Deb, thank you so much for sharing that. My dad passed some years ago, but it’s still very real today. I keep thinking i can pick up the phone and call him.

On the puzzle: i thought it was a fine Thursday. Thanks for your bits of help!

Deb. I cried a little reading your column. What an open and honest description of your experience.

My father was a WW2 combat vet, a wonderful yet flawed man who carried serious emotional injury until the day he died. I too was there.

I heard someone say that there isn't a man who wouldn't give anything to have 15 minutes more with his father. I see that this applies to woman as well. Not a surprise, but I hadn't thought about it before, focusing on my own loss and desire for a little more time to say how much I love him.

Fun puzzle. 

A bit quick for a Thursday, but that's okay.

not a great puzzle. COMMONCORE isn't a great clue... i was looking for 3/4/5 letter runs in the middle of the clue trying to suss out what is being alluded to. a 'core' is not literally everything except 1 piece. that's well beyond the definition of core. the clue didn't allow the solve.

also, AOL was originally an ISP, not a tech giant.
'bruh' is not used interchangeable with 'my man!' that would be 'bro' or dude'
cute.  easy for a thursday, but fun!
aw, deb, i cried reading your column today.  so beautiful.  thank you.  i'll be holding you in my thoughts as you grieve.

The puzzle was good, and fun to solve, but my reason for commenting is to add my condolences, Deb, on your father's passing.

Deb, I am so sorry for your loss of your father. Your column was a beautiful tribute to him. It sounds like he was a wonderful man and father. I take solace in the good memories, and it sounds like you’re doing the same. Take care of yourself.

Bravo to the constructor(s) and editors today. Great puzzle, very clever!
@Deb I'm so sorry for your loss and am thankful to your dad for the gift of YOU!

Sorry for your loss, Deb, of your dad. I have two feisty daughters and they're my favorite kind. I love them as much as I know your dad loved you, and am as proud of them as much as he was  proud of you. You are one of my favorite people, having helped me a lot to get started as a pretty decent NYT crossword solver in my eighties. Bless you and carry on!

Deb - Thank you for your beautiful tribute to your dad.  It made me think of my grandfather and my mother who both did the NY Times crossword puzzles on paper in ink.  I learned from them but do them online now.  It is not as messy to correct my errors.

Deb, so sorry to learn of your father's passing.

A while back I read an article in which a rabbi was asked 
about a feeling a mourner had after her mother's death.

The rabbi said, " What you may be experiencing is the presence of absence."

Those words resonated with me and made me cherish memories all the more.

Deb, I wish you and your family peace of mind and peace of heart.

deb, what a beautiful tribute to your dad.

I still don't quite get 46 across: I see press kit and the word ski, but what goes with ski to become mountain lodge activity?

This was a really lovely puzzle that made me feel both frustrated and smart. All the best puzzles do that and this one met me in exactly the right place. Tons of fun cluing that clicked when it clicked. And a clever little theme that didn't require the rosetta stone to parse.

One thing that stood out for me. I will echo the sentiments that BRUH is not a positive exclamation that stands in for bro or dude. It is a sarcastic/disappointed stand-in for "seriously bro?" but you say it completely deadpan without the upward inflection. My qualification for knowing this is that I am the father of two boys, ages 12 and 14. Otherwise known as 'taking one for the human race'. You're welcome and thank you.

@Deb

My mom passed a few months ago. She was 103. After she moved to FL from NY, I would call her on Saturday mornings. Sometimes, in the middle of the conversation, I could tell I had lost her for a moment. Then she would suddenly say, "What's a five letter word for...." and I knew she was doing a crossword while we were talking. Normally she would do them with my dad, but by then Alzheimer's had stolen the puzzles from him. 

After he passed. she moved up to Massachusetts, to be near my sister. By the time she reached 100, puzzles were starting to be a thing of the past. But now that she is gone, I know that she and Dad are watching me as I do them, poking each other, and trying to put the right answers into my head. 

Grief takes time. Let it move through you, but leave yourself open to the memories. As we say, "May his memory be a blessing." I find the memories are wonderful, and make great stories to pass on. Especially when there's no one around to correct them!
Definitely a tricky clue. Though the hardest one for me was AMMAN- since I google it and Ammon was a thing
I feel privileged today, to have read such a beautiful tribute and memorial of love. I don’t know you, Deb, but thank you for your openness to share your story of your Dad.
My condolences on the loss of your beloved father, Deb.  Thank  you for sharing such beautiful memories with us, and thank you for doing the work you love every day.
Interesting that apres ski, not a very common entry, appears here today and apres ski quaff also appears on WSJ puzzle today!

Deb, I enjoy reading your column after (or as) I try to solve the puzzle. Reading this personal tribute to your dad and picturing how you started with your love of crosswords was moving. Thank you for sharing and heartfelt condolences to you and your family.
How about "Weird contractions" for spasms?
Deb, thank you for your touching tribute. Condolences.

Vivek H. Murthy, MD, the Surgeon General of the United States, has written a timely book. It's, titled, " Together", ( the healing power of human connection in a sometimes lonely world). 
  Deb you and Dad were able to share a connection via crosswords. I can see why you might tear up while continuing the path that Dad set for you. Peace.
My sole sticking point was 50A "My man!" as BRUH. Having never seen nor heard of this, I put in the MUCH MORE COMMON version "BRAH."

lovely tribute, Deb. my condolences 💛

this is my favorite kind of puzzle, one that seems tough, maybe even undoable on the first pass but after a few passes  it all falls into place :)

Deb, I am so sorry to hear about your loss of your father. I do think you have written a very fine and substantial tribute to him here. It meant a lot.

In other news I think I am back to normal. I didn’t use any word-check for the first time in months on Thu-Sat but I did read Deb’s column, saw the answer key(for STEELY instead of Steady) and am still flyspecking! Wonderful puzzle. I always like Rebecca Goldstein. And I liked Adam Wagner’s use of the word “sprezzatura” to describe her style of wordplay. Thanks, All!

My sincere condolences, Deb. Welcome back. 

I did a Thursday without any checking! Not my very first time but still feels like a triumph! 🥳

Lots of comments about BRUH.  

I originally had BROH, but I think as a solver you have to be ready to interchange vowels, especially with a slang or onomatopoeia.  So while I don't recall ever hearing BRUH, it didn't surprise me.

I had more trouble with APRESSKI as part of 46A.  Never heard of it.  Then again, I've never had the money to hand around in ski lodges.
Wow, was not expecting a tearjerker in the blog today… deepest condolences, Deb. May he rest in peace. What a blessing that you were able to share the time and experiences with him that you did.

So sorry for your loss, Deb - lovely tribute to your Dad.

Fun puzzle. Did not know the factoid in 29D - my own Dad, who passed away just shy of 94 some years ago, was part of those high numbered troops in India.

Beautiful tribute to your father, Deb.  I lost mine before I was four so I envy you!  My Mom introduced crosswords to my older brother, but mourning my Dad, didn't with me. 

My younger daughter brought me to crosswords as she and friends needed the puzzle in college after the subscription ended there.  I loved the puzzles and still do. 

Great Thursday puzzle, Ms. Goldstein and Mr Wagner.  Keep working together, please.
David Lynch, the king of "Weird flexes" died today. RIP MR LYNCH!

Deb, that was a lovely tribute to your father. It's wonderful you are able to make a lifelong passion into your job.

Also for the millionth time, marketing does not put together a PRESS KIT... public relations does.

Thank you for sharing your heart with us, Deb. Your tribute to your dad is so lovely and honest. It's hard to carry the regrets of time and opportunities lost.

My dad died when he was 46, and I will always regret our last parting. He was standing in the driveway to say goodbye. It occurred to me to give him a hug (not a thing we were big on) and say "I love you," but I was 18 and cool older friends were in the car waiting for me, so I just ran past him with a quick wave and headed back to college, never expecting that I'd never see him again.

He was a good man but not an easy man; there were a lot of demons there, but I so very much wish I'd have done better.

It taught me that while I can't change that day, I can do my absolute best to ensure no one else I love dies without knowing I love them. I've learned that grief is love that doesn't quite know where to go... that it's not a thing to get over but, once it's not quite as acute, to make room for and to feel the love.

I hope you'll be easy on yourself about your regrets. Your dad sounds like he would admire feistiness, so I've no doubt he was actually very proud of you for the strong person you are, despite the conflicts—as much as he was proud of you for your crossword success. I'm so happy for the warm times you had together and that you brought him such comfort in the end. That's everything!

My deepest condolences. 💖

I am just here to echo the condolences that many have expressed. Deb, I’m very sorry for your loss. My dad would have been 99 this year, so of a similar generation to yours. And like you, we had a relationship that was pretty difficult at times. I was pretty young when he died, and often wish I had the opportunity as a more mature adult to have a better relationship. I’m glad that you were able to enjoy his last years in peace together.
Sincere condolences, Deb. It's clear his memory is a blessing, which is how it should be. As others have said, we are all the better for his influence on you. Thanks for that.

Dear Deb, your memories will keep your dad alive forever. Your eulogy is caring and honest. I realize only now, at 82, that my mom and dad loved me so much and that I never realized the depth of their love until my own grandchildren have nearly fledged and left the nest, my nest. How many times have I wished to tell my parents I’m sorry I never asked what they felt; what it was like to live through the times that they did; to forgive my carelessness. My own children and grandchildren are often told that I love them. My oldest grandson knows much more about me than anyone else.  I hope I am passing along what it has taken me so long to learn.

May peace come along with time and know that wanting to “talk” to your dad is normal. HeathiJ has wisdom for both of us. We all love you, Deb. Write again.
That really was an enjoyable Thursday puzzle.  No tricks or rebus  ... just fun.  Thanks!

Condolences Deb.

And a few parallels & coincidences...

I too lost my Dad on 1/6 at the age of 91
(in 2014)

And he served in the RCAF in WW2.

And while he was not my crossword catalyst
as an actor announcer humorist and writer
he filled our house with reading and wordplay.

Puns captions word puzzles newspapers 
and shaggy dog stories abounded.

Mum was my Scrabble wingwoman and guru.

Simultaneously during all of the above...
HOCKEY was the other passion in our houses.

Mum & Dad's first date was to a Leafs game 
at the "Church on Carlton" and 3 nights
before I was born he and my VERY pregnant 
mother watched Toronto win game 1 of the 
Stanley Cup Finals -- in STANDING ROOM!

He turned the tickets down -- Mum insisted on going!

Our team added 3 more BROS later...

So yeah our house was full of -- 
PUCKS & BROS & BREWS...

But no BROHS or BRUHS or BRAHS
and very few BRAS.

So 2 things I know better than most in life
crisscrossed and were my 
ONLY error on this grid???!!!

My Mum would not have gotten it.
And my Dad woulda groaned over 
both GOAL SEEKERS and BRUH.

So, in their honor, I am giving myself a PERFECT 
regardless of what the bots and apps say.

So yeah, like wow eh?

My condolences Deb. A lovely and heartfelt tribute to your father. 

Can someone explain the answer to 55 down? I got it (ETA) but don’t understand the connection to the clue (H).
Beautiful story. So similar to mine and now I’m crying, too. Thank you so much for sharing. Sending you lots of love
Much sympathy for your father’s passing Deb.
By the way, great photo pick for today, Deb.

Sorry for your loss, Deb. Thanks for sharing a little about him. You’re an incredible writer. 

Now, I’ll go call my dad.

Oh, Deb. My dad died just a few days before yours, and I feel every bit of what you said, so much. He too wanted so much to have more time to be with my Mom, us kids, and the grandkids. He wasn't a crossword guy, but he and my Mom would print out two copies of an "evil"-level Sudoku each night and race each other to solve it. I have done quite a few crosswords (and read quite a few Wordplay columns) since he passed, and indeed while spending his last night in the hospital watching over him as he slept. Distraction and ritual help at least a little, so your words and the work of the Games team have helped me. My best to you and your family.

I’m so sorry for your loss, Deb. Losing a parent is so hard and it colours everything that comes afterwards. I’m glad you have happy crossword memories with him—thank you for sharing with us. Thinking of you and your family and sending big, big hugs.

Hello, everyone,

I just wanted to pop in and thank all of you for your heartfelt and thoughtful messages. They mean so much to me, and I feel so lucky to be a part of this community.
Sorry for your loss Deb. I feel for you.
Terrible puzzle

So sorry for your loss, Deb.  Didn’t expect to get teary eyed from reading the crossword column but so it goes.  It was heartfelt and beautifully written and brought back memories of my father, who hardly noticed me, taking the time one day to show me how to work the crossword and the importance of 1-across.   I’d bet anything that your dad cherished the memories of doing the puzzles with you as much as you do.  Can’t imagine how proud he was of you, even if he didn’t always know how to show it.

So sorry to hear about your dad, Deb. My dad passed about about a year and a half ago. He wasn't much for crosswords, but every now and then, when I would be at my parents house working on the puzzle online, he'd stand over my shoulder and give an answer for one of the clues. Then he'd walk away saying, "Ha! I got one." I miss him terribly.
how do you get "sega" from Peter Gabriel?
Thanks for sharing with all of us.  Such a gift to everyone here.  Welcome back.
Thanks for sharing with all of us.  Such a gift to everyone here.  Welcome back.

Dear Deb,

I came here looking for help…and boy did I find something else, and yet something akin to help.  I’m so sorry for your loss, but having gone through almost exactly what you went through- a few years prior- I can empathize (down to holding hands until very end).  However, unlike your father who gave you the gift of crossword joy, my father (for still some unfathomable reason) did not care for crosswords.  Anytime I would shout out a clue I didn’t know, but thought for sure he would know, I’d get either an answer, a question as to why I wasn’t solving the thing by myself, or both.  What made this all the more mysterious to me as to why he didn’t seem to enjoy crossword puzzles was this was the very man who instilled in me a love of words and literature and the power of knowledge (and many other invaluable lessons and incredible memories of what it means to be a loving and caring parent).  So, without having even gotten to the “tricky clues” portion, thank you Deb for bringing your wit and wisdom and thank you for your father for creating that special bond that brought you to all of us who look forward to your column every week!

Deb, my heart goes out to you. I join the many commenters here in offering my deepest sympathy for the loss of your father. It was very generous of you to share such a beautifully written, touching tribute with all of us.

Wonderful puzzle. Maybe not the toughest Thursday, but I’m not complaining. Very clever wordplay and theme.
Very disappointed that the cover picture isn't Pauly Shore in BIODOME

deb, what a gorgeous remembrance of your dad. i am so sorry for your loss. how incredible that you shared a love of puzzles. i love the story about him asking for your "help" when you were a child, since i used to do something similar with my son, who is now 21yo and my daily crossword solving companion.

i'm surprised to see so many complaints about the puzzle. i thought it was very clever and great fun.
Thank you, Deb, for your warm, moving remembrance and tribute to your dad.  Today’s Wordplay column will not be forgotten.  I am sorry for your loss, but glad that you had your dad for so many years.

Thank you for sharing those beautiful sentiments about your Dad, Deb.  You brought a smile to my face as I recalled my mom doing the crossword regularly and asking me for help occasionally.  I'm very sorry for your loss, but very happy you have great memories and the all important reconciliation to appreciate in times when you feel low.  Peace.

Thank you Deb for such a wonderful intro and for sharing such a lovely memory. All the best to you and your family.

Ms Goldstein and Mr. Wagner, that was one of the funnest puzzles I've done in a long time.  It reminded me of the clever puzzles from many years ago.  That's meant as a compliment.  Thank you.
Oh Deb, how eloquent. Thank you for allowing us to know your Dad a little. Be blessed
Deb, I'm so sorry for the loss of your dad. What a beautiful tribute you wrote.

Thank you Deb for this tribute to your father.

I, too, was introduced to crossword puzzles by my father.  He was a dentist, and his office was much closer to my high school than our house.  I would walk there after school and sit in the employee break room to do my homework, then get a ride home with him after work.

Most days the crossword was sitting on the table, not finished.  I'd try to fill in where I could -- pop culture was my forte in those days, compared to the 'old people' in the office, of course.

I lost him 30 years ago.  He was only 75 -- my age now!  It was also cancer....  He was hale and hearty and playing golf regularly until about 6 weeks before he died.  He had quit all the chemo and radiation about 6 months earlier because it wasn't helping and just made him feel sick.  

We are blessed to have great dads!
Thanks for your story, Deb. It has rung true for many of us here in Napa

Thank you Deb, for that very moving and honest tribute to your dad. I know all our hearts go out to you. It brought tears to my eyes, partly because I didn’t really have a dad when I was growing up.
Thank you to for the columns you write. 
And thanks, Rebecca and Adam, for a terrific puzzle today. Thursdays are almost always my favorites and this one was both tricky and fun.
Why is PRE “what follows TSA weirdly?”

My condolences for your loss, Deb, and thank you for sharing such personal reflections about your relationship with your father. My thoughts are with you and your family. May his memory be a blessing.

Steven M.,

I usually start at the top of a puzzle and work down, so my "big giveaway" was the topmost themer at 17A. The next themer, your "big giveaway," was a fast second. I'm a bit over 35, but I would have gotten the theme just as quickly from the second themer (Incredible as that may seem).

I found this a clever but easy Thursday.
@Steven M. Some of us over 35 have kids…

@Chris 

What Chris said.  I'd guess it's "most" of us, and that if you throw in nephews and friends and such AND the quality of that first movie (the second not so much) and the memorability of the character, I'd venture to say that Edna's a happy little gimme for the majority.  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Puzzlemucker 
For whatever reason that song is my quintessential summer song. It reminds me of driving (relatively) fast down a highway with the windows rolled down, volume way up and the wind whipping through my hair.
@B I was afraid that maybe this was an easy puzzle because I didn’t need too mich help.
@Wayne Harrison  Exactly where I was stuck as well. Couldn't get how PaCKS could be "goal seekers" and had to resort to Wordplay for the first time in a while.
@TMD Simply because PRE means before. Like you, I overthought that one.

@TMD

I think it's that PRE usually refer to something that comes before, as in prefix, but for T.S.A. PRE it comes after. I've never thought of that as being weird, though.
@Cathy I remain lost, and that E was the last letter to fall.  PRE as in Precheck at the Airport?  I'm not generally up this early.  Perhaps my brain will wake up.
@Joe On the signs at the airport it usually says "TSA Pre" which struck him as backwards.

@Joe

Yes, as in precheck at the airport. Their logo looks like TSA Pre✓ so maybe it makes more sense if you see it written like that. I had STEADY instead of STEELY so that was near the end for me too.

@TMD

It's for TSA Pre check.  Some of us who fly a lot pay for the priviledge of being in a shorter line and not having to take our shoes off.  It's $85 for five years, and worth every penny!

So I know that -- but didn't figure it out for the answer to the clue.

@Janine

@Bill    XD    love it.
Condolences, Ms. Amlen, on the loss of your father.

@Joan 
I first "solved" with my Granny after she was widowed in the mid-Sixties.  When she lost most of her eye-sight, I began helping her with various tasks--writing checks, balancing the checkbook, reading the mail, ordering books from Library for the Blind, and filling in the crossword puzzles.  She had a long history with the puzzles in the 'Atlanta Constitution' and back in those days, many obscure oddities were the stuff of fill.  (Think Maleska.)  I learned MERL and similer crosswordese fill vocabulary.  By the time I finished high school, another solution was necessary, and we moved her into Wesley Woods (independent supported living for elderly folk.)  I have fond memories of finding her playing bridge with large-numeral cards, wearing a green eye-shade to cut the glare....

@Jane Wheelaghan 
"Mob scene" (brouhaha); "obscenest" (most appalling)
"Press kit" for marketing fodder
TSA Pre-Check (at the airport)
H is the Greek letter eta.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Likewise. A "mob scene" seems to be pretty much a riot, according to the online Merriam-Webster. Whereas a brouhaha is a hubbub or uproar, according to the same source. Both accord with my understanding in BrE.
I'd be quite surprised if anyone ever gor tear-gassed during a brouhaha.

"Press kit" I'm familiar with from the documents NASA used to hand out to journalists before the Apollo missions, which are now all available online, and make interesting reading.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

I'm with you about brouhaha being rather lesser to mob / mob scene. And all I know of the Greek alphabet came from these puzzles! I always need crossing help on those. 

'Mob scene' is a colloquialism, such as "I tried to get an autograph after the show, but it was such a mob scene around the star I had to give up and go home."

A 'press kit' is just that: a packet provided to the media (a.k.a. the press) to promote something. An example could be a public relations firm sending a product sample along with a press release in hopes of getting said product written up in the a magazine...

@Andy The only problem is that "involuntary flex but ok" is not a meme. Whereas "weird flex but ok" is. It is a common response to someone who is proud of something that they should arguably not be proud of ('flex' meaning 'boast').

@americongrl "apres" as in "APRES SKI(T)"
@americongrl "apres ski' is a pretentious thing that rich people say about sitting around in the lodge having drinks by the fire after they are finished skiing. It is french for 'after ski'.

Scott,

Many of your skiing countrymates -- and a fair number of European skiers --  say it without pretension ... and with or without wealth.

@Barry Ancona I suppose we can agree to disagree on what qualifies as "without pretension". If I ever said it out loud I hope I would have the sense to be embarrassed about it. It's something that you say because you are rich and you think it's a normal thing people say or because your are not and you want to sound like you are. I suppose I could be wrong but if I'm wrong on facts I'm right on vibes. It's an unredeemably cringe inducing phrase.
@Barry Ancona I can't speak to the European experience obviously

@Cathi I agree with you, Deb's tribute to her dad was touching, and brought back my own memories. My mother was the crossword maven; she would cut the crossword out of the paper so it was easier for her to work on. She would carry it in her purse when she was waiting at the doctor's office....she loved knowing rarely used words that appeared frequently in the puzzle  (example: "pismire"!) As she grew older, she started falling behind, and I would find stacks of half-finished crosswords around her apartment. It was on Christmas night ten years ago that she died, and I'm a digital subscriber (so, no evidence lying around my house), but I owe my love of crossword puzzles to her.
